content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Mai Nguyen: I was born in San Jose, California, to parents who both grew up in Vietnam. We moved here when I was just a baby, and I've always considered the U.S. my home, even though I carry a deep connection to my heritage. My childhood was pretty typical—my parents worked hard to provide for our family, and I grew up in a close-knit neighborhood where everyone knew each other. I lived with my parents and my younger brother until I went to college. My mom worked as a nurse, and my dad was a mechanic, both of them having only finished high school. Despite their limited education, they always encouraged me to pursue my dreams. I was the first in my family to go to college, and I ended up earning a graduate degree in social work. It wasn't an easy path—there were times when money was tight, and I had to work part-time while studying, but I always felt supported by my family. I married my husband, who's also Vietnamese, and we've built a life together here in San Jose. We have two kids, and I still work full-time, though I've made it a priority to be there for them as much as possible. Life has had its challenges, but I've always believed in the value of education, hard work, and family.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Mai Nguyen: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped my path. When I was in my second year of college, I had the opportunity to work as a volunteer at a local community center that provided support services to immigrants and low-income families. At the time, I was struggling to balance my studies, a part-time job, and taking care of my younger brother while my parents were working late shifts. But that experience at the community center opened my eyes to the challenges many families face, especially those like mine who had recently immigrated. I saw how much of a difference someone could make by being there for others, and it made me realize that I wanted to dedicate my career to helping people in similar situations. I decided to switch my major to social work, even though it meant starting over with some courses and taking on more debt. It was a tough decision, but looking back, I know it was the right one. That crossroads taught me the importance of using my education not just for personal success, but to give back to the community that raised me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Mai Nguyen: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. It felt like the universe was nudging me in that direction. I remember sitting in my dorm room one night, looking at the photos of my parents and my brother, and thinking about how far we had come. I realized that if I had the chance to make a difference in someone else's life, even in a small way, I had a responsibility to do so. It wasn't just about my own dreams anymore—it was about the legacy I wanted to leave for my family and the community that had given me so much. I made the decision that night, and I've never regretted it.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Mai Nguyen: Absolutely. I remember that the community center I volunteered at had a mentorship program, and one of the social workers there, Ms. Lin, took me under her wing. She shared her own story of growing up in a similar situation and how she found her way into social work. Her guidance was invaluable—it helped me see the path more clearly and gave me the confidence to make the switch. I also had support from my parents, who, even though they didn't fully understand what social work entailed, believed in me and encouraged me to follow my heart. I think it's important to recognize that no one does it alone. There were people who saw potential in me and offered support when I needed it most.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Mai Nguyen: Yes, I have a partner and two children. My husband, Minh, is also Vietnamese, and we met in college through a mutual friend. He works as an IT specialist, and while our careers are different, we share a deep respect for each other's dedication and hard work. We have a daughter, Lily, who's eight, and a son, Ethan, who's five. Raising them in San Jose has been both a blessing and a challenge. I want them to grow up with a strong sense of their Vietnamese heritage, so we celebrate our traditions, speak Vietnamese at home, and take them to cultural events whenever we can. At the same time, I want them to feel comfortable in their American identity. It's a balance, but I think they're doing well. My parents are still very involved in their lives, and I'm grateful for that. My mother helps with the kids a few days a week, and my father, though he's not as active as he used to be, still enjoys spending time with them. Family is everything to me, and I'm so proud of the life we've built together.

Going through these interview questions brought back a lot of memories and made me reflect on how far I've come. Starting with the story of my life, it felt like a journey of gratitude—for my family, my heritage, and the opportunities I've had. Thinking back to that crossroads in college, I realize how pivotal that moment was in shaping who I am today. It wasn't just a decision; it was a calling, one that I felt deeply in my heart. I'm grateful for the people who supported me along the way, like Ms. Lin and my parents, who believed in me even when I wasn't entirely sure of myself. Now, as I look at my family—my husband, my children, and my parents—I feel a deep sense of fulfillment. I've built a life that honors my roots while embracing the future, and I'm proud of the path I've chosen.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Mai Nguyen: My brother, Tony, is also a big part of my life. He's six years younger than me, and we've always had a close relationship, even though we grew up in a busy household. He ended up going into the restaurant business, owning a small Vietnamese eatery in San Jose. It's been a dream of his for years, and I'm so proud of him for making it happen. We don't see each other as often as I'd like because of our busy schedules, but whenever we do, it's like no time has passed. He's always been the fun-loving one, the one who keeps our family laughing, and I know I can always count on him. Our parents are really close with him too, and I think that's one of the reasons our family has always been so supportive of each other. Even though we've all taken different paths in life, we're still connected by our shared roots and the love we have for one another.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Mai Nguyen: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, a childhood friend from our neighborhood. We grew up together, and even though we've both taken different paths in life, we still keep in touch. She's a teacher now, and she's always been someone I can talk to about anything—whether it's about work, family, or just life in general. She's been there for me through some of my toughest times, and I know I can always rely on her. Then there's my friend David, who I met through the community center where I volunteered. He's a counselor, and he's been a great support system for me both professionally and personally. He's helped me navigate some of the challenges in my career and has always encouraged me to keep pushing forward. I think it's important to have people in your life who genuinely care about you and are there for you when you need them most.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Mai Nguyen: I live in a neighborhood that feels like a little piece of both worlds—Vietnamese and American. It's in San Jose, near the downtown area, but still has that community feel that I remember from when I was growing up. There are a lot of Vietnamese families here, which makes me feel at home, but there are also a lot of other cultures represented, which I love. The streets are lined with small businesses, from local bakeries to family-owned restaurants, and every weekend, there are cultural festivals and food markets that bring everyone together. I enjoy walking around the neighborhood, especially on weekends, because it's full of life and energy. There's a community garden nearby where I sometimes volunteer, and it's a nice way to connect with other residents. I also like that the schools in the area are good, and I feel confident that my kids are getting a well-rounded education. Even though I've been here for most of my life, I still find new things to appreciate about this place every day.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Mai Nguyen: I feel very safe in my neighborhood. There's a strong sense of community here, and people look out for one another. I've lived here for most of my life, and I've never felt threatened or unsafe. The local police department is responsive, and there are neighborhood watch programs that keep things under control. Plus, with so many families living here, especially from Vietnamese and other Asian backgrounds, there's a natural sense of trust and familiarity. I've seen people help each other out during tough times, whether it's fixing a car, watching kids while someone works late, or just offering a friendly word. It's not perfect, but I feel secure in my home and in the streets I walk every day.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Mai Nguyen: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, I love the sense of community and the cultural diversity. It's a place where I can feel connected to my roots while also being part of something bigger. The local Vietnamese community is very supportive, and I've made lifelong friends here. The schools are good, the parks are nice, and there's always something happening—whether it's a festival, a food truck event, or a community meeting. But it's not without its challenges. Like anywhere, there are moments when things feel overwhelming—raising two kids, working full-time, and trying to keep up with the cost of living. Sometimes I feel like I'm juggling too many things at once. But I remind myself that this is the life I chose, and I'm grateful for the opportunities this neighborhood has given me. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood brought up a lot of emotions and reflections. Talking about my partner, children, and parents reminded me of how much my family means to me and how grateful I am for the life we've built together. It also made me think about the importance of maintaining our cultural roots while embracing the opportunities this country has given us. When I described my neighborhood, I felt a deep sense of pride in the community we're part of—a place that feels like home and where I can raise my kids with both their Vietnamese heritage and American identity. It was also comforting to talk about feeling safe and connected in my neighborhood, knowing that there's a strong sense of support and belonging. Even though life here has its challenges, I've come to appreciate the balance of culture, community, and family that makes this place special to me.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Mai Nguyen: A typical week for me is pretty full, but I try to keep a balance between work, family, and community. I start my week early, usually around 6:30 a.m., when I get up to make breakfast for the kids and get them ready for school. My husband helps out too, and we take turns with the morning routine. I work full-time as a social worker at a nonprofit that supports immigrant families, so I'm usually at the office by 8:30 a.m. My days can vary a lot—some days are spent in meetings or training, while others involve visiting clients in their homes or attending community events. I try to leave work by 5 p.m. so I can be there for the kids when they get home from school. On weekdays, I pick them up, help with homework, and we have dinner together. On the weekends, we try to do something fun—whether it's going to a park, visiting a cultural festival, or just having a quiet family movie night. I also make time to volunteer at the community garden a couple of times a week, which is a nice way to stay connected with the neighborhood. It's not always easy, but I find comfort in the rhythm of the week and the people who make it all possible.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Mai Nguyen: I work as a social worker at a nonprofit organization called Community Bridges, which focuses on supporting immigrant families and individuals facing housing insecurity, domestic violence, and access to healthcare. I work full-time, from around 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday. My days are pretty varied—I might spend the morning in meetings with other social workers and case managers, or I might be out in the field, visiting clients in their homes or accompanying them to appointments. I also do a lot of outreach work, especially during the holidays or times when there are community events. It can be emotionally demanding at times, especially when I see families struggling, but I find it incredibly rewarding to be able to make a difference in their lives. I've been in this role for about seven years now, and it's become a big part of who I am. I always tell my kids that I'm not just their mom—I'm also someone who helps other families, just like their grandparents helped us when we first came to this country.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Mai Nguyen: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to wake up early every morning, even on weekends, to have some quiet time before the kids are up. I enjoy making coffee, reading a chapter of a book, and sometimes meditating or doing a few yoga stretches. It's my way of starting the day with intention. I also make it a point to cook traditional Vietnamese meals at least a few times a week—it's not just about the food, but about connecting with my heritage and giving my kids a taste of home. On the weekends, when I'm not volunteering at the community garden or attending cultural events, I like to take long walks in the park near our house. It's a peaceful place where I can clear my mind and reflect on the week. I also have a small bookshelf in my living room filled with books on social work, parenting, and even some novels in both English and Vietnamese. Reading is a way for me to continue learning and growing, and I hope to pass that love of learning on to my kids as well.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Mai Nguyen: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I've been trying to set aside 10 minutes each day for guided meditation, which has helped me manage the stress of work and family life a bit better. I also started a small habit of journaling in the morning, just a few sentences about how I'm feeling or what I'm grateful for. It's something I learned from a workshop at the community center, and I've found it really helps me stay centered. Another change is that I've been trying to spend more quality time with my kids after school, especially in the afternoons. I used to be on my phone a lot while they were doing homework, but now I make it a point to sit with them, ask them about their day, and help them with their assignments. It's been a small but meaningful shift that's brought us closer together.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Mai Nguyen: During the school year, my kids have a pretty structured routine. They wake up at 7:00 a.m., and after a quick breakfast, they leave for school by 7:45 a.m. Both of them attend the same elementary school here in San Jose, which has a strong focus on multicultural education. After school, they usually have a snack and then do some homework or creative activities. Lily, my daughter, is into art and music, so she often joins the after-school art club and takes piano lessons twice a week. Ethan, my son, loves sports—he plays soccer on a local team, and he also participates in a STEM club that meets every Tuesday. I try to pick them up by 5:30 p.m., and we have dinner together as a family. After dinner, we usually have some quiet time—Lily reads or does her homework, and Ethan plays with his toys or watches a bit of TV. On weekends, we try to do something more active, like going to the park or visiting a museum. I think it's important for them to have a balance between academics, hobbies, and family time. It's not always perfect, but I feel like we're giving them the best foundation we can.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my family, neighborhood, and daily life shape who I am. Talking about my family reminded me of the deep love and support we share, and how important it is to pass on our cultural heritage to my children while also embracing the opportunities this country has given us. Describing my neighborhood brought back a sense of pride in the community we're part of—a place where I feel safe, connected, and at home. Reflecting on my job as a social worker made me realize how much I've grown since that crossroads in college, and how grateful I am to be able to give back to the community that raised me. Thinking about my daily routines and responsibilities reminded me of the balance I strive for every day—between work, family, and personal growth. Even though life can be overwhelming at times, I find comfort in the rhythm of my week and the people who make it all possible. It's a life I've built with purpose, and I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Mai Nguyen: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in good shape, though I've had my share of challenges over the years. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid—I loved playing outside with my brother, riding my bike around the neighborhood, and helping my parents with small chores around the house. As I got older, I started to realize the importance of taking care of my body, especially with the demands of work and family. I try to stay active by walking or doing light yoga a few times a week, and I make sure to eat healthy meals, even if it's not always easy with a busy schedule. I do have some chronic issues, like mild back pain from sitting at my desk for long hours, and I sometimes struggle with stress-related headaches, especially during busy times at work. I've learned to manage these by taking short breaks throughout the day, practicing deep breathing, and making sure I get enough rest. I also see a doctor regularly and have a good relationship with my primary care physician, who helps me stay on top of any health concerns. Overall, I feel lucky to be in good health, and I try to pass on that mindset to my kids by encouraging them to eat well, stay active, and take care of their bodies.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Mai Nguyen: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a strong support system—my family, friends, and the community around me. I know I can count on my husband to remind me to take breaks or go for a walk when I'm feeling overwhelmed. My kids also keep me active, whether it's playing in the park or helping them with their homework. But what makes it hard is the constant juggling of work, family, and personal time. There are days when I'm so busy that I forget to eat properly or skip my morning walk. I've learned to be kind to myself and not get discouraged when I slip up. It's not about being perfect—it's about making small, consistent choices that add up over time. I also find that staying connected to my cultural traditions helps me feel grounded, and that mental well-being is just as important as physical health.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Mai Nguyen: In the past two years, I actually had a minor surgery to repair a herniated disc in my lower back, which had been causing me some chronic pain and limiting my ability to stay active. It wasn't something I wanted to deal with, but I knew I couldn't ignore it anymore, especially since I wanted to keep up with my kids and continue working full-time. The recovery was tough—there were days when I felt frustrated or even a little depressed because I couldn't do the things I used to do without pain. But I'm glad I went through with it. Now, I'm much better, and I've started incorporating more physical therapy into my routine to strengthen my core and prevent future issues. It was a reminder that taking care of my health isn't just about staying active or eating well—it's also about listening to my body and seeking help when I need it. I've learned a lot from that experience, and I hope my kids will understand the importance of taking care of themselves, both physically and emotionally, as they grow up.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Mai Nguyen: Honestly, there were times when the pain made it hard to focus on work or be fully present for my kids. I remember one particularly tough week after the surgery when I was still in physical therapy and couldn't bend down to help Ethan with his homework or play with Lily in the park. It was frustrating because I wanted to be there for them, but my body was holding me back. I had to learn how to ask for help—whether it was my husband stepping in more or my parents helping out with the kids when I needed rest. It also made me realize how important it is to prioritize self-care, not just for my own health but so I can be the best version of myself for my family. I've come to see that taking care of my health isn't a luxury—it's a responsibility, especially when you're the one your kids look up to and rely on.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Mai Nguyen: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions. On one hand, I've been really grateful for the progress I've made in my health after the surgery. I'm able to walk longer distances without pain, and I've even started going to yoga classes again, which has been a huge relief. I feel more energized and connected to my body, which has helped me be more present for my kids and my work. On the other hand, there have been moments of uncertainty, especially with the ongoing challenges of the pandemic and the rising cost of living. I've had to make some tough decisions, like cutting back on certain expenses or working extra hours to make ends meet. It's been a year of resilience, but also of learning to be more flexible with my expectations. I've also been reflecting a lot on my role as a mother and a community worker, and I've come to appreciate how much I give to others, but also how important it is to take time for myself. I've started setting aside small moments each day just for me—whether it's reading a book, listening to music, or even just sitting quietly with a cup of tea. It's not much, but it's helped me feel more balanced and grounded.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily routines, health, and the challenges I face shape my overall well-being. Talking about my recent changes to my morning routine—like mindfulness and journaling—reminded me of how small, intentional habits can have a big impact on my mental and emotional health. Discussing my health brought up both the struggles and the progress I've made, especially after my surgery. It was a humbling reminder that taking care of my body is just as important as taking care of my family and my work. I also realized how much my support system—my family, friends, and even my community—helps me stay grounded and resilient. It's not always easy to balance everything, but knowing that I have people who care about me makes all the difference. I'm grateful for the journey I've been on and for the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Mai Nguyen: I think I've experienced moments of anxiety, especially during the pandemic when everything felt so uncertain. There were days when I worried about my kids' education, my job, and even my health. I remember feeling overwhelmed by the weight of it all, like I was carrying the world on my shoulders. But I've learned to talk about it—whether it's with my husband, my friend Sarah, or even my therapist. I used to think that showing vulnerability was a weakness, but now I see it as a strength. It's okay to not be okay sometimes. I've also started practicing mindfulness more regularly, which has helped me manage my thoughts and emotions. I'm not saying I've completely conquered anxiety, but I'm learning to live with it and not let it define me. I want my kids to know that it's okay to feel scared or stressed, but it's also okay to reach out and ask for help when you need it.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Mai Nguyen: For my family, the past year has been a mix of challenges and growth. My husband has been incredibly supportive, especially during my recovery from surgery. He took on more responsibilities at home, and I'm so grateful for his patience and understanding. Our kids have also been through a lot—they've had to adjust to remote learning at times, and I've seen them struggle with the isolation and uncertainty. But they've also shown a lot of resilience. Lily, in particular, has been really focused on her art and music, using it as an outlet for her emotions. Ethan has been more active in his soccer team, which has helped him stay grounded. My parents have been a big part of our lives too—they've been helping with the kids when we need it, and they've been there to offer advice and comfort. It's been a tough year, but I feel like we've come out stronger as a family. We've learned to lean on each other more, and I think that's something we'll carry with us for a long time.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Mai Nguyen: For me, religion has always been a source of strength and comfort. I was raised Catholic, just like my parents, and even though life has been busy, I try to keep that connection alive. I attend Mass every Sunday when I can, and I find that the sense of community in the church is something I really value. It's not just about the rituals or the teachings—it's about the feeling of belonging and the reminder that I'm not alone in this life. My faith has helped me through some of my toughest moments, especially during my recovery from surgery and the stress of work. I also find peace in the quiet moments, like lighting a candle or saying a prayer before bed. I want my kids to know about our faith, not just as a tradition, but as a way to find meaning and hope in life. Even if they don't follow the same path as me, I hope they understand the importance of kindness, compassion, and believing in something bigger than themselves.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Mai Nguyen: I do use social media, though not as much as some of my friends. I have a Facebook account where I keep in touch with family and old friends from our neighborhood. I also follow some local community pages that post about cultural events, school activities, and volunteer opportunities. It's a good way to stay connected with what's happening in our area without having to leave the house. I don't use Instagram or other platforms as much because I find them a bit overwhelming with all the constant updates and comparisons. But I do use Facebook to share photos of my kids, especially when they do something special like winning a soccer game or showing off their art. It's also where I keep track of my parents' health and make sure I don't miss any important family events. I think social media can be a useful tool if you use it mindfully, and for me, it's more about staying connected with the people I care about rather than keeping up with trends.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Mai Nguyen: Honestly, I've found that Facebook has been a quiet source of support during tough times, even if I don't use it as much as others. When I was recovering from my surgery, I posted a few updates about how I was feeling, and to my surprise, a lot of people from my community reached out with messages of encouragement or even shared their own stories of recovery. It was comforting to know that I wasn't alone in my struggles, and it reminded me of the power of connection, even through a screen. I also remember when my parents were going through a health scare a few years back—I used Facebook to keep my extended family updated, and it helped everyone stay in the loop without having to call or visit constantly. It's not the same as being there in person, but it's a way to stay close and show support, especially when life gets busy. I think it's important to use these platforms not just for sharing the good times, but also for the hard ones, because sometimes just knowing someone is thinking of you can make all the difference.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on my health journey and the emotional challenges I've faced over the past year. Talking about my herniated disc surgery reminded me of how vulnerable I felt during recovery, but also how grateful I am for the support of my family and the progress I've made since then. It was also meaningful to discuss my struggles with anxiety, especially during the pandemic, and how I've learned to embrace vulnerability as a strength rather than a weakness. Sharing these experiences with my family and friends has helped me feel less alone, and I'm proud of how we've all grown through the challenges together. I've come to understand that my health is not just about physical well-being, but also about emotional resilience, and I hope to pass that understanding on to my children as they navigate their own lives.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Mai Nguyen: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted—some days feel lighter, and others still carry the weight of uncertainty. The pandemic has left a lasting impact, and even though things are more stable now, I still worry about the future, especially with the rising cost of living and how it affects my family. I've been trying to be more intentional with how I handle stress. I've started journaling more regularly, not just in the mornings but also at night, which helps me process my thoughts and emotions. I've also found that spending time in nature, even if it's just a short walk in the park, helps me reset. I've been more open with my family about my feelings too, which has created a deeper sense of connection. My husband and I have started having weekly check-ins where we talk about how we're feeling, and that's been really healing. I'm learning that it's okay to not have all the answers, and that taking small steps toward emotional well-being is just as important as any physical health routine.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Mai Nguyen: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to our kids' school supplies, extracurricular activities, and healthcare costs. Both Lily and Ethan are in after-school programs, and those fees add up, especially with Lily's piano lessons and Ethan's soccer team. We also had to pay for some dental checkups and a few prescriptions after my surgery. Rent is another major expense—we live in a two-bedroom apartment that's not too far from the city, but it's still a chunk of our budget. Groceries are another thing; I try to cook most meals at home, but with two kids and my work schedule, it's not always easy to stick to a strict budget. We also have car payments and insurance, which are necessary but can be stressful when unexpected costs come up. I've been trying to track our spending more carefully, and we've cut back on some non-essential things like dining out or shopping for new clothes. It's not always easy, but I remind myself that we're doing our best, and that our kids are growing up in a safe, loving environment. I'm grateful for the support of my family and the community, and I know we'll keep finding ways to make it work.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Mai Nguyen: Last month, our household spent around $3,500, which is actually a bit higher than usual. Normally, we spend closer to $3,000 a month, but with the cost of living rising and some unexpected expenses, like the dental visits and a new pair of shoes for Ethan after he outgrew his old ones, it added up. Our biggest fixed costs are rent, which is about $1,500, and car payments and insurance, which total around $600. Then there's the groceries, which we try to keep under $500, but with two kids and my work schedule, it's not always easy. The after-school activities and piano lessons are another recurring expense—around $300 a month. I've been trying to track everything more carefully, and we've cut back on things like eating out or buying new clothes unless it's necessary. It's a tight budget, but we make it work by being mindful and relying on our support system. My parents help out with the kids sometimes, and we've also started using community resources for things like free school supplies or food assistance programs when needed. It's not perfect, but we're doing our best to provide for our family and keep our heads above water.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Mai Nguyen: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment in a neighborhood that's close to both the schools and the community center where I work. Renting has always been the practical choice for us, especially with the rising costs of homeownership in this area. My husband and I have considered buying a house at some point, but with our current financial situation and the uncertainty of the market, it just doesn't feel like the right time. Renting gives us more flexibility, especially with our kids' needs changing as they grow. Plus, it's easier to manage with my parents helping out with the kids sometimes—we don't have to worry about maintenance or repairs, which is a relief given how busy our lives are. I know it's not the same as owning a home, but for now, it's a good fit for our family.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Mai Nguyen: Over the past year, my bills have definitely fluctuated depending on the time of year and what's going on with the kids. For example, during the school year, we have more expenses related to after-school activities, like Lily's piano lessons and Ethan's soccer team. We also pay for school supplies, uniforms, and sometimes even transportation passes for them. In the summer, those costs go down a bit, but we end up spending more on things like summer camps or family trips. Holidays are another big factor—around Christmas and Lunar New Year, we tend to spend more on food, gifts, and family gatherings. We also have seasonal utility costs, like higher electricity bills in the summer when we use the air conditioner more, and heating costs in the winter. I've been trying to track these changes more closely, and it's helped me plan better. For instance, we set aside a little extra each month for the holidays so we're not caught off guard. It's not always easy, but knowing how our expenses shift throughout the year has made it easier to manage our budget and stay on top of things.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and the support systems around me have helped me navigate the challenges of the past year. Talking about my health struggles reminded me of how important it is to lean on the people I love, especially during tough times. It also made me think about how my faith has been a source of strength, giving me a sense of purpose and connection even when life feels overwhelming. Discussing my use of social media brought up how, even in small ways, staying connected with others can make a big difference in how we feel about ourselves and our circumstances. I'm grateful for the people in my life—my family, friends, and community—who have been there for me, and I hope to continue being a source of support for them as well.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Mai Nguyen: I try to save whenever I can, even if it's just small amounts. I have a savings account that I contribute to every month, usually around $100, which I set aside automatically so I don't forget. It's not a lot, but it gives me some peace of mind, especially knowing that unexpected things can happen—like a sudden medical expense or a car repair. I also have a separate jar at home where I put aside loose change from my kids' allowance or any spare coins I find. It's a way to teach them about saving, and it's also a little reminder for me to stay disciplined. I know we're not wealthy, and I don't expect to be, but I believe in planning for the future, even in small ways. My parents always taught me that saving is a habit, and I'm trying to pass that lesson on to my kids. It's not about having a lot—it's about being prepared, and I think that's something that's going to serve us well in the years to come.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Mai Nguyen: For me, saving has always been more about preparing for the unexpected rather than a specific big purchase like a home. In the last year, I've been focusing on building an emergency fund, even if it's just a small amount each month. I know that life can be unpredictable—whether it's a sudden medical expense, a car repair, or even a temporary loss of income—and I want to make sure we're not caught off guard. I also save a little extra during the months when our expenses are lower, like in the summer, so we can use that money for things like school supplies or holiday gifts later on. It's not about being rich, but about having a little cushion so we can handle life's surprises without falling apart. I've seen how hard it can be for families who don't have that safety net, and I want my kids to grow up knowing that being prepared is just as important as working hard.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Mai Nguyen: My occupation has always been deeply meaningful to me. I work as a social worker at a nonprofit organization called Community Bridges, where I focus on supporting immigrant families and individuals who are facing challenges like housing insecurity, domestic violence, and limited access to healthcare. My days are never the same, which is both challenging and rewarding. Some days, I'm in meetings with other social workers and case managers, discussing strategies to better serve our clients. Other days, I'm out in the field, visiting clients in their homes or accompanying them to appointments, which requires a lot of empathy and patience. One of the most important parts of my job is building trust with the people I work with—many of them have come from difficult situations, and they need someone they can rely on. I also do a lot of outreach work, especially during the holidays or times when there are community events, which allows me to connect with people in a more personal way. It's not an easy job, but I find it incredibly fulfilling to be able to make a difference in someone else's life. I always tell my kids that I'm not just their mom—I'm also someone who helps other families, just like their grandparents helped us when we first came to this country.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Mai Nguyen: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it can sometimes stretch a bit longer depending on the needs of the families we serve. My schedule is pretty consistent—Monday through Friday, from about 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., but there are days when I stay late to finish up paperwork or attend a meeting. I also do some work from home occasionally, especially when I need to prepare for client visits or review case files. It's not always easy balancing work with everything else, but I've learned to be flexible and prioritize what matters most. I know that my job is important—not just for the people I help, but also for my own sense of purpose. It's a demanding role, but I wouldn't trade it for anything because I feel like I'm making a real difference in people's lives, and that gives me a deep sense of fulfillment.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Mai Nguyen: No, I haven't had more than one job throughout most of my life. I've always focused on my work as a social worker because it aligns so closely with my values and the life I want to build for my family. However, when I was in college, I did work part-time at a local grocery store to help support my studies and my family. It was a tough balance, but I learned a lot from that experience—about responsibility, time management, and the importance of hard work. After I graduated and started my career in social work, I committed myself fully to that path. It's been a long journey, but I've never felt the need to take on additional jobs because I believe in the impact of the work I do. That said, there have been times when I've worked extra hours or taken on additional responsibilities at my job, especially during busy periods or when families are in crisis. I've always tried to be present for my kids and my community, and I think that balance has been key to who I am today.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my stress, emotional coping strategies, and financial situation have shaped my daily life and sense of well-being. Talking about my stress levels reminded me of how much I've grown in learning to manage anxiety and uncertainty, especially with the ongoing challenges of the pandemic and rising costs of living. It also made me realize how important it is to have open conversations with my family about how I'm feeling, and how those check-ins have strengthened our bond. Discussing my monthly budget and expenses brought up the reality of balancing financial responsibilities while still providing for my family in a way that feels secure and loving. It's not always easy, but I've come to appreciate the small ways we make it work—whether it's relying on my parents for support, cutting back on non-essential expenses, or using community resources when needed. I'm grateful for the resilience we've built together and for the lessons I've learned about prioritizing both emotional and financial well-being.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Mai Nguyen: In total, our household made around $5,200 in the past month. That comes from my full-time salary as a social worker and my husband's income as an IT specialist. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and some of our monthly expenses. I've been trying to be more mindful of how we spend our money, especially with the rising cost of living. We've had to make some tough choices, like cutting back on dining out or delaying non-essential purchases, but I feel good about the balance we've struck. I'm also grateful that my parents help out with the kids sometimes, which eases some of the financial pressure. It's not always easy, but I believe we're doing our best to provide for our family and build a stable future for our children.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Mai Nguyen: I've been working at Community Bridges for about seven years now, and it's become such a big part of my life. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance is one of the most important things, especially after my surgery. I have access to medical, dental, and vision coverage, which has been a huge relief. We also get paid time off, including vacation days and sick leave, which is something I really appreciate because it allows me to take care of myself and my family when needed. There's also a small stipend for professional development, which I've used to attend workshops on trauma-informed care and cultural competency. I think it's important for social workers to keep learning, especially when working with such a diverse population. The workplace itself is pretty supportive, and I've built strong relationships with my colleagues. We often have team meetings where we share experiences and support each other through the challenges of the job. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm part of something bigger than myself, and that gives me a sense of purpose every day.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Mai Nguyen: My relationships at work are very supportive and collaborative. I have a great relationship with my manager, who I'll call Ms. Thompson. She's been with the organization for over a decade, and she truly understands the challenges we face as social workers. She's always been approachable, whether it's for guidance, feedback, or just a listening ear when things get overwhelming. I feel like she genuinely cares about her team and our well-being, which makes a huge difference in such a demanding job. As for my coworkers, we've built a strong sense of camaraderie over the years. We often share stories, support each other through tough cases, and even have lunch breaks together when we can. There's a real sense of community in our office, and I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to stay committed to this work for so long. It's not just about the job—it's about the people I get to work with and the impact we make together.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Mai Nguyen: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a fair amount of flexibility depending on the needs of the families we serve. I usually start at 8:30 a.m. and finish by 5 p.m., but there are days when I stay a bit later to wrap up a case or attend a meeting. I also have the option to work from home a couple of days a week, which has been helpful, especially when I need to manage family responsibilities or take care of myself. That said, I don't always know exactly what my day will look like when I wake up—sometimes I'm in the office, sometimes I'm out visiting clients, and other times I'm on the phone with a colleague or a client. The flexibility is something I really appreciate because it allows me to be present for my kids and my community, but it also means I have to be organized and adaptable. I've learned to plan my days as best as I can, but I'm always ready for the unexpected.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Mai Nguyen: Overall, I feel like we're managing, but it's not without its challenges. I know we're not wealthy, and I don't expect to be, but I believe in the value of what we have. My husband and I both work hard, and we've built a life that's stable enough to provide for our kids and keep a roof over our heads. I also feel grateful for the support of my family and the community around us. Sometimes, I worry about the future—about whether we'll be able to keep up with the rising costs of living or if my kids will have the same opportunities I had. But I also know that we're doing our best, and that's something I can be proud of. I've learned that financial security isn't just about having a lot of money—it's about knowing that you're doing what you can, and that you're not alone in it. I hope my kids grow up understanding that, and that they know they can always count on their family and their community to help them through whatever comes next.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation, work schedule, and savings habits shape my daily life and sense of security. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the importance of planning and being mindful of our expenses, especially with the rising cost of living. It also made me think about how my job as a social worker, while meaningful, comes with its own financial realities—like the need to save for unexpected expenses and the balance between work and family. Discussing my savings habits brought up how small, consistent efforts to set money aside, even in modest amounts, can provide a sense of stability and peace of mind. I'm grateful for the support of my family and the community, and I hope to continue teaching my kids the value of financial responsibility and preparation for the future.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Mai Nguyen: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My mom was a nurse, and my dad was a mechanic. They both worked full-time jobs, though they only had high school educations. It wasn't easy for them—especially in the beginning, when they were just trying to establish themselves in this country. My mom worked long hours at the hospital, and my dad would come home exhausted after working at the garage. But they never complained. They always made sure that my brother and I had food on the table, clothes on our backs, and a place to sleep. I remember seeing them sacrifice so much, like buying second-hand furniture or skipping meals so we could have something to eat. It taught me the value of hard work and resilience. I always tell my kids that their grandparents didn't have much, but they gave everything they had to make sure we had a better life. That's one of the reasons I chose to go to college and pursue a career that would allow me to give back to others in the same way they gave to me.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Mai Nguyen: My mom was a nurse, and my dad was a mechanic. My mom's job was incredibly demanding—she worked long shifts at the hospital, often 12 hours a day, and she was always the first one to arrive and the last one to leave. Her most important duties were caring for patients, administering medications, and making sure they were comfortable. She had a heart of gold, and I remember seeing her comfort a sick child or hold a grieving family member's hand. She always said that her job wasn't just about the medical care, but about showing compassion. My dad, on the other hand, worked at a local auto shop. He was the kind of person who could fix anything—cars, appliances, even the plumbing if needed. His most important activities were diagnosing problems, repairing vehicles, and making sure his customers left with their cars running smoothly. Both of them had a strong work ethic, and they always made sure that my brother and I had what we needed, even if it meant sacrificing their own comfort. I think that's one of the reasons I wanted to pursue a career in social work—to honor the sacrifices they made and to help others the way they helped me.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Mai Nguyen: My mom worked at a local hospital in San Jose, and my dad worked at a small auto repair shop in the same neighborhood. My mom was employed by a nonprofit healthcare clinic that served a lot of low-income families, including many immigrants like us. She didn't just do the clinical work—she was also a source of comfort and support for patients who were scared or in pain. She often stayed late to make sure patients had what they needed, whether it was a warm blanket or someone to talk to. My dad worked for a family-owned auto shop that had been in business for decades. He was the lead mechanic, and he was known in the community for his honesty and skill. He would fix cars, but he also fixed relationships—he always took the time to explain things to his customers in a way they could understand, and he never charged more than what was fair. Both of them worked hard, not just for themselves, but for their family. I remember watching them sacrifice so much, and it's one of the reasons I wanted to do something that would help others, just like they helped me.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Mai Nguyen: A few years from now, I hope to still be doing the work I love, helping families in our community just as I have been. I want my kids to see me as someone who is passionate about making a difference, not just as a mom or a social worker, but as someone who believes in the power of kindness and support. I also hope that my health continues to improve, so I can keep up with them as they grow and explore the world. I dream of one day being able to take them on a trip back to Vietnam, to show them where their grandparents came from and to give them a deeper connection to our roots. I hope we're still living in this neighborhood, surrounded by the same sense of community that has always made me feel at home. And most of all, I hope that my family is happy, healthy, and united, because that's what matters most to me. I know life will always have its challenges, but I also know that with love, support, and a little bit of faith, we can face anything together.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Mai Nguyen: What I value the most in my life is the love and connection I have with my family. My parents, my husband, my children, and even my extended family and friends—they are the foundation of everything I do. I value the sense of community we have here in San Jose, where people look out for one another and support each other through good times and bad. I also value the opportunities this country has given me, especially the chance to pursue my education and build a career that allows me to give back to others. But above all, I value the lessons I've learned through the challenges I've faced—about resilience, compassion, and the importance of staying grounded in who you are, no matter where life takes you. I want my kids to grow up knowing that they are loved, that they are capable of making a difference, and that they can always find strength in their roots and their relationships.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my financial situation, work schedule, and the support I receive at my job all contribute to the balance I try to maintain in my life. Talking about our household income reminded me of how much my husband and I work to provide for our family, and how grateful I am for the stability we've built, even if it's not perfect. Discussing my job at Community Bridges brought back a sense of pride in the work I do, and how it's not just about the paycheck, but about the impact I can have on others' lives. It also made me think about the flexibility of my schedule and how important it is to have a job that allows me to be present for my kids and my community. I'm grateful for the support I receive from my manager and coworkers, and I know that without that sense of teamwork and understanding, it would be much harder to keep going. These reflections reminded me that while life can be challenging, I have a strong foundation to rely on, and that gives me hope for the future.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective journey for me. It reminded me of how far I've come—from a child of immigrant parents working hard to provide for their family, to the first in my family to go to college, and now to a social worker helping others just as they helped me. It also made me think about the choices I've made, like switching my major to social work, and how that crossroads in college truly shaped who I am today. Talking about my family, my neighborhood, my job, and even my health brought up so many emotions and memories, but it also gave me a sense of gratitude for the life I've built. I'm proud of the path I've chosen, even with all its challenges, and I'm grateful for the support of my family, friends, and community. This interview has reminded me that my story is not just about my successes, but also about the struggles, the lessons, and the love that have brought me here. I hope that by sharing it, I can inspire others to find their own purpose and embrace the journey, no matter how difficult it may be.
